title: New Bianchi Specialissima RC is faster and illegally light
content:
Cyclist
New Bianchi Specialissima RC is faster and illegally light

Bianchi has launched its third generation Specialissima RC. It describes the new bike as a next-gen all-round race bike and claims a 6.6kg complete bike weight with a size 55 frame, under the UCI’s 6.8kg minimum weight limit. While the Specialissima has always been designed to excel on climbs, the new bike has enhanced aerodynamics over its predecessor, leading, Bianchi says, to higher performance on the flat and on descents too.

The top spec Specialissima RC has lost the Countervail vibration damping tech of the previous bike, but this is still present in the next level down Pro grade frame. There’s also an entry level Comp frameset, which again omits Countervail.

Bianchi hasn’t disclosed prices as yet.

Related Posts

Faster than an aero bike on a 6 percent climb

Bianchi claims a market-leading stiffness-to-weight for the new Specialissima RC, with RC standing for Reparto Corse and designating the top grade frameset, which it says is the choice for grand tour GC riders.

When we reviewed the previous generation Specialissima, we weighed it at 7.15kg, so the claimed 6.6kg for the new bike in the same size 55 represents a significant decrease.

Bianchi says that its goal with the new bike was to improve on the old model’s aerodynamics while retaining its low weight and responsiveness, so that the gradient at which it became more efficient than its Oltre RC aero bike is just 6.2%, whereas the old model needed a gradient of 8.8% to achieve this tipping point.

Bianchi claims that this equates to an 8.7 second advantage over the older model on a 10km long 6% for a rider delivering 200 watts. If you can keep up 30kmh on such a climb, Bianchi says that the new model will save you 3.6 watts. On the flat, it claims that the new bike’s advantage over the old is increased to over 30 seconds over 10km.

As you’d expect, the new Specialissima RC borrows plenty of aero tech from the Oltre RC, including the fork profile, the frame-to-fork interface and the D-shaped seatpost.

Bianchi says that it has also beefed up the head tube area to improve its aero properties while slimming down the rear of the bike to reduce weight overall. This looks like the latest trend in road bike design, as we’ve already seen a similar approach in the new Specialized Tarmac SL8 and the recently launched Ridley Falcn RS.

The new Specialissima RC also gets lightweight paint that loses 40g. It’s another approach to shedding a few grams that has been used elsewhere, including the latest Orbea Orca and Ineos Grenadiers Pinarello Dogma F bikes. There are also weight reductions in the Specialissima’s derailleur hanger and seatpost clamp.

Yet more weight loss comes from the one piece bar-stem with internal cable/hose routing, which Bianchi says weighs 330g in 110x380mm size. It offers a total of 17 length/width combinations.

The Specialissima RC also has its own wheelset, the Reparto Corse 33R, with a claimed weight of 1,380g. The rims are 33mm deep, 21mm internal width, 28m external, tubeless ready, compatible with tyres up to 32mm wide, and built on Ceramitech hubs. 

There’s a high performance RC139 carbon saddle fitted that weighs a claimed 145g.

The Specialissima RC is available with Shimano Dura-Ace or SRAM Red AXS groupsets, in both cases with a power meter.

Three Specialissima specs

Although the top-of-range tech is applied to the RC bikes, Bianchi will also offer the Specialissima in Pro and Comp variants.

The Specialissima Pro, like the new Giant Defy Advanced Pro, isn’t actually the bike geared to pro riders, but to keen amateurs. It’s kitted out with the same aero cockpit as the RC but, unlike the RC, includes the Countervail, a feature designed to dissipate vibration, that Bianchi incorporates into many of its other bike frames, including the previous generation Specialissima.

The Pro spec has a choice of Shimano Ultegra or SRAM Force AXS groupsets. 

Wheels are swapped out for Velomann Palladium with 33mm deep, 21mm internal width rims and a 1,460g claimed weight, but which have a similar rim profile to the Reparto Corse 33R wheel rims of the Specialissima RC. There’s a Velomann saddle, with both the saddle and wheels coming from Bianchi’s own sub-brand. The paint options gain a bit of weight, but include metallic celeste and grey alternatives. Bianchi claims a 7.0kg complete bike weight, still not bad at all.

Finally, the Comp variant provides compatibility with Bianchi’s higher spec components, including its one-piece bar-stem, in a more affordable package. Groupset options are Shimano Ultegra, Shimano 105 Di2 or SRAM Rival AXS. There’s a separate alloy bar and stem and the same Velomann Palladium wheelset as fitted to the Pro spec. Bianchi says that the Comp weighs 7.8kg.

You can choose between celeste and a graphite finish that Bianchi describes as ‘intriguing’.

Bianchi will sell the Specialissima in six sizes: 47, 50, 53, 55, 57 and 59, with availability from end-September. There’s a frameset-only option for all frame grades.

There’s no word from Bianchi on pricing for the new bike.
